I had high hopes for this game but I have to give a scathing review. This game is boring. Instead of being a game that allows you to care for your Tgotchi and seeing the impact of your long term actions
column6: it's a short ended
column7: rail-guided
column8: get-the-same-ending-because-you-don't-hace-a-choice story with no way to progress. I don't like how much this game was hyped up when it did not exceed let alone meet any expectations. It's got a good concept but the execution is horrible. I want my money back..

column4: Interesting app. Probably better to think of this more like an interactive story than a game. You are railroaded very hard
column5: intentionally. Doing everything right ends up with your gotchi killing herself
column6: which forces you to do things wrong on purpose to see more content. Once you've seen every other ending
column7: the last ending is unlocked. It is impactful
column8: but less so because you can't make many choices in the game. And there are a lot of elements included which go nowhere and seem pointless.

I'm a huge fan of virtual pets
column6: but I was not too thrilled with this app. It tries to be a horror game
column7: where the girl comes down with illness and depression from being neglected by the owner - the player - but it doesn't feel as if the player is neglecting her by choice. The game is full of arbitrary time skips
column8: then claiming the player was neglecting their T-Gotchi
column9: even though they've been doing their best to feed and wash her on every day the game lets you. The player is supposed to feel bad for neglecting the girl
column10: but the player doesn't actually choose to neglect her. The player doesn't forget to feed her
column11: or just get bored and not check for a few weeks
column12: the game *tells* the player they neglected her
column13: rather than actually letting the player do so. I think it would have achieved what it was going for much more if it ran in real time
column14: with the player being expected to check on her at various points throughout the day
column16: the player would get tired of the game
column17: and stop checking up on her
column18: but when they do one day genuinely decide to log back into the game
column19: they would see what effects the players neglect is having on the girl. I think that would have been much more impactful. This doesn't strike me as either a good vpet
column20: or a good horror game. Just a game with a somewhat decent concept that was messed up.
